qa_pairs.question: How did the share of renewable energy in Portugal's electricity generation change between 2022 and 2023, and what was the primary reason cited for this increase?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>The share of renewable energy in Portugal's electricity generation increased from 49% in 2022 to 61% in 2023.<cite>[S6]</cite></statement> <statement>The primary reason cited for this increase was favorable weather conditions, according to the grid operator REN.<cite>[S7]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.chunk:
Passage 1:
[S1] Electricity sector in Portugal


# Electricity sector in Portugal



In 2008, Net electricity use in Portugal (gross production + imports – exports – losses) was 51.2 TWh. [S2] Portugal imported 9 TWh electricity in 2008. [S3] Population was 10.6 million. [S4] In 2018 electricity was generated by 23% hydroelectricity, 26% natural gas, 22% wind, 20% coal, 5% biomass, 2% solar and 2% oil. [S5] In 2019 electricity was generated by 19% hydroelectricity, 32% natural gas, 26% wind, 10% coal, 6% biomass, 2% solar, 2% oil and 1% other combustibles. [S6] By 2023, the share of renewable power sources of Portugal's electricity rose to 61% (from 49% in 2022). [S7] Grid operator REN attributes the record percentage to favorable weather conditions. [S8] Portugal aims to generate 85% of its electricity from renewables by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2045, five years ahead of its initial target. [S9] ## Main power stations


## Hydro

The pumped-storage hydroelectricity plant at Frades works as 880 MW for generation and 780 MW for pumping. [S10] ## Wind power

Portugal produced 20% of electricity with wind power in 2017 and had the average year capacity of 14% of wind power in the end 2010. [S11] Wind power capacity was 3,357 MW in end 2009 and 3,702 MW in end 2010. [S12] | EU and Portugal Wind Energy Capacity (MW) | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| No | Country | 2012 | 2011 | 2010 | 2009 | 2008 | 2007 | 2006 | 2005 | 2004 | 2003 | 2002 | 2001 | 2000 | 1999 | 1998 |
| - | EU-27 | 105,696 | 93,957 | 84,074 | 74,767 | 64,712 | 56,517 | 48,069 | 40,511 | 34,383 | 28,599 | 23,159 | 17,315 | 12,887 | 9,678 | 6,453 |
| 6 | Portugal | 4,525 | 4,083 | 3,898 | 3,535 | 2,862 | 2,150 | 1,716 | 1,022 | 522 | 296 | 195 | 131 | 100 | 61 | 60 |


## Solar power

In Lisbon, the energy payback time (see also EROEI) in the roof top solar photovoltaic (PV) technology is less than 2 years and less than in Sydney, Munich, Athens or Barcelona, but some more than in Madrid, Los Angeles or Ankara. [S13] ## Transmission

Redes Energéticas Nacionais manages the high voltage power lines. [S14] In 2014, Portugal had an electricity interconnection level (international transmission capacity relative to production capacity) of 7%, below the recommended 10% level.
chunk_list:
[S1] Electricity sector in Portugal


# Electricity sector in Portugal



In 2008, Net electricity use in Portugal (gross production + imports – exports – losses) was 51.2 TWh. [S2] Portugal imported 9 TWh electricity in 2008. [S3] Population was 10.6 million. [S4] In 2018 electricity was generated by 23% hydroelectricity, 26% natural gas, 22% wind, 20% coal, 5% biomass, 2% solar and 2% oil. [S5] In 2019 electricity was generated by 19% hydroelectricity, 32% natural gas, 26% wind, 10% coal, 6% biomass, 2% solar, 2% oil and 1% other combustibles. [S6] By 2023, the share of renewable power sources of Portugal's electricity rose to 61% (from 49% in 2022). [S7] Grid operator REN attributes the record percentage to favorable weather conditions. [S8] Portugal aims to generate 85% of its electricity from renewables by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2045, five years ahead of its initial target. [S9] ## Main power stations


## Hydro

The pumped-storage hydroelectricity plant at Frades works as 880 MW for generation and 780 MW for pumping. [S10] ## Wind power

Portugal produced 20% of electricity with wind power in 2017 and had the average year capacity of 14% of wind power in the end 2010. [S11] Wind power capacity was 3,357 MW in end 2009 and 3,702 MW in end 2010. [S12] | EU and Portugal Wind Energy Capacity (MW) | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| No | Country | 2012 | 2011 | 2010 | 2009 | 2008 | 2007 | 2006 | 2005 | 2004 | 2003 | 2002 | 2001 | 2000 | 1999 | 1998 |
| - | EU-27 | 105,696 | 93,957 | 84,074 | 74,767 | 64,712 | 56,517 | 48,069 | 40,511 | 34,383 | 28,599 | 23,159 | 17,315 | 12,887 | 9,678 | 6,453 |
| 6 | Portugal | 4,525 | 4,083 | 3,898 | 3,535 | 2,862 | 2,150 | 1,716 | 1,022 | 522 | 296 | 195 | 131 | 100 | 61 | 60 |


## Solar power

In Lisbon, the energy payback time (see also EROEI) in the roof top solar photovoltaic (PV) technology is less than 2 years and less than in Sydney, Munich, Athens or Barcelona, but some more than in Madrid, Los Angeles or Ankara. [S13] ## Transmission

Redes Energéticas Nacionais manages the high voltage power lines. [S14] In 2014, Portugal had an electricity interconnection level (international transmission capacity relative to production capacity) of 7%, below the recommended 10% level.

qa_pairs.question: What were the key differences in electricity generation sources between 2018 and 2019, and how did these changes reflect Portugal's energy strategy?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>In 2018, electricity generation in Portugal was composed of 23% hydroelectricity, 26% natural gas, 22% wind, 20% coal, 5% biomass, 2% solar, and 2% oil, while in 2019, the shares shifted to 19% hydroelectricity, 32% natural gas, 26% wind, 10% coal, 6% biomass, 2% solar, 2% oil, and 1% other combustibles. The key differences include a decrease in hydroelectricity (23% to 19%), an increase in natural gas (26% to 32%), growth in wind power (22% to 26%), a significant reduction in coal (20% to 10%), and a slight rise in biomass (5% to 6%).<cite>[S4][S5]</cite></statement><statement>These changes reflect Portugal's energy strategy of transitioning toward renewables and reducing reliance on fossil fuels, as evidenced by the long-term goal of generating 85% of electricity from renewables by 2030 and achieving carbon neutrality by 2045. The decline in coal and increase in wind power align with the strategy to prioritize cleaner energy sources, while the rise in natural gas may indicate a transitional role in balancing grid stability during the shift to renewables.<cite>[S8]</cite></statement>

qa_pairs.question: What are Portugal's targets for renewable energy and carbon neutrality, and how do they compare to previous goals?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Portugal aims to generate 85% of its electricity from renewables by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2045, five years ahead of its initial target. The 2045 carbon neutrality goal represents a five-year advancement compared to previous targets, though the passage does not specify the original timeline for carbon neutrality.<cite>[S8]</cite></statement>

[S8] Portugal aims to generate 85% of its electricity from renewables by 2030 and achieve carbon neutrality by 2045, five years ahead of its initial target. [S9] ## Main power stations


## Hydro

The pumped-storage hydroelectricity plant at Frades works as 880 MW for generation and 780 MW for pumping. [S10] ## Wind power

Portugal produced 20% of electricity with wind power in 2017 and had the average year capacity of 14% of wind power in the end 2010. [S11] Wind power capacity was 3,357 MW in end 2009 and 3,702 MW in end 2010. [S12] | EU and Portugal Wind Energy Capacity (MW) | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |

## Solar power

In Lisbon, the energy payback time (see also EROEI) in the roof top solar photovoltaic (PV) technology is less than 2 years and less than in Sydney, Munich, Athens or Barcelona, but some more than in Madrid, Los Angeles or Ankara. [S13] ## Transmission

Redes Energéticas Nacionais manages the high voltage power lines. [S14] In 2014, Portugal had an electricity interconnection level (international transmission capacity relative to production capacity) of 7%, below the recommended 10% level.
